attributes.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.
attributes.description: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Nitrogen Mass in Products of Land-Use Change

attributes.comment: Primary (organic carbon) production by the picophytoplankton (<2 um) component alone

attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
attributes.longname: Net Primary Mole Productivity of Carbon by Picophytoplankton

attributes.comment: E.g. fruits, seeds, etc.
attributes.description: E.g. fruits, seeds, etc.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Carbon Mass in Vegetation Components Other than Leaves, Stems and Roots

attributes.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.
attributes.description: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
attributes.longname: Sinking Particulate Organic Nitrogen Flux

attributes.comment: including sapwood and hardwood.
attributes.description: including sapwood and hardwood.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Nitrogen Mass in Stem

attributes.comment: any harvested carbon that is assumed to decompose immediately into the atmosphere is reported here
attributes.description: any harvested carbon that is assumed to decompose immediately into the atmosphere is reported here
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Harvested Biomass That Goes Straight into Atmosphere as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: E.g. fruits, seeds, etc.
attributes.description: E.g. fruits, seeds, etc.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Nitrogen Mass in Vegetation Components Other than Leaves, Stem and Root

attributes.comment: The uptake of nitrogen by fixation: nitrogen fixation means the uptake of nitrogen gas directly from the atmosphere.
attributes.description: The uptake of nitrogen by fixation: nitrogen fixation means the uptake of nitrogen gas directly from the atmosphere.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Plant Nitrogen Uptake (Sum of Ammonium and Nitrate) Irrespective of the Source of Nitrogen

attributes.description: Primary (organic carbon) production by the diatom component alone
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
attributes.longname: Net Primary Organic Carbon Production by Diatoms

attributes.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Nitrogen Mass in Vegetation

attributes.comment: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass).

attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Mass of 13C in Vegetation

attributes.comment: Net upward flux of methane (NH4) from wetlands (areas where water covers the soil, or is present either at or near the surface of the soil all year or for varying periods of time during the year, including during the growing season).
attributes.description: Net upward flux of methane (NH4) from wetlands (areas where water covers the soil, or is present either at or near the surface of the soil all year or for varying periods of time during the year, including during the growing season).
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Grid Averaged Methane Emissions from Wetlands

attributes.comment: leached nitrogen etc that goes into run off or river routing and finds its way into ocean should be reported here.
attributes.description: leached nitrogen etc that goes into run off or river routing and finds its way into ocean should be reported here.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Lateral Transfer of Nitrogen out of Grid Cell That Eventually Goes into Ocean

attributes.comment: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.
attributes.description: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Deforested or Harvested Biomass as a Result of Anthropogenic Land-Use or Change

attributes.comment: The fixation (uptake of nitrogen gas directly from the atmosphere) of nitrogen due to biological processes.
attributes.description: The fixation (uptake of nitrogen gas directly from the atmosphere) of nitrogen due to biological processes.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Biological Nitrogen Fixation

attributes.comment: Flux of carbon-14 as carbon dioxide into the land. This flux should be reproducible by differencing the sum of all carbon pools (cVeg, cLitter, cSoil, and cProducts or equivalently cLand) from one time step to the next, except in the case of lateral transfer of carbon due to harvest, riverine transport of dissolved organic and/or inorganic carbon, or any other process (in which case the lateral_carbon_transfer_over_land term, see below, will be zero data).
attributes.description: Flux of carbon-14 as carbon dioxide into the land. This flux should be reproducible by differencing the sum of all carbon pools (cVeg, cLitter, cSoil, and cProducts or equivalently cLand) from one time step to the next, except in the case of lateral transfer of carbon due to harvest, riverine transport of dissolved organic and/or inorganic carbon, or any other process (in which case the lateral_carbon_transfer_over_land term, see below, will be zero data).
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Net Mass Flux of 14C Between Atmosphere and Land (Positive into Land) as a Result of All Processes [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: Flux of carbon-13 into the atmosphere due to plant respiration. Plant respiration is the sum of respiration by parts of plants both above and below the soil. It is assumed that all the respired carbon dioxide is emitted to the atmosphere.
attributes.description: Flux of carbon-13 into the atmosphere due to plant respiration. Plant respiration is the sum of respiration by parts of plants both above and below the soil. It is assumed that all the respired carbon dioxide is emitted to the atmosphere.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Carbon-13 Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to Autotrophic (Plant) Respiration on Land [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: Total flux of Nitrogen from the land into the atmosphere.
attributes.description: Total flux of Nitrogen from the land into the atmosphere.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Nitrogen Lost to the Atmosphere (Sum of NHx, NOx, N2O, N2)

attributes.comment: Anthropogenic flux of carbon as carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. That is, emissions influenced, caused, or created by human activity. Anthropogenic emission of carbon dioxide includes fossil fuel use, cement production, agricultural burning and sources associated with anthropogenic land use change, except forest regrowth.
attributes.description: Anthropogenic flux of carbon as carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. That is, emissions influenced, caused, or created by human activity. Anthropogenic emission of carbon dioxide includes fossil fuel use, cement production, agricultural burning and sources associated with anthropogenic land use change, except forest regrowth.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Carbon Mass Flux from Vegetation, Litter or Soil Pools into the Atmosphere Due to any Human Activity [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area in soil.
attributes.description: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area in soil.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Mass of 14C in Soil Pool

attributes.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.
attributes.description: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
attributes.longname: Sinking Particulate Organic Phosphorus Flux

attributes.comment: Flux of carbon 31as carbon dioxide into the land. This flux should be reproducible by differencing the sum of all carbon pools (cVeg, cLitter, cSoil, and cProducts or equivalently cLand) from one time step to the next, except in the case of lateral transfer of carbon due to harvest, riverine transport of dissolved organic and/or inorganic carbon, or any other process (in which case the lateral_carbon_transfer_over_land term, see below, will be zero data).-
attributes.description: Flux of carbon 31as carbon dioxide into the land. This flux should be reproducible by differencing the sum of all carbon pools (cVeg, cLitter, cSoil, and cProducts or equivalently cLand) from one time step to the next, except in the case of lateral transfer of carbon due to harvest, riverine transport of dissolved organic and/or inorganic carbon, or any other process (in which case the lateral_carbon_transfer_over_land term, see below, will be zero data).-
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Net Mass Flux of 13C Between Atmosphere and Land (Positive into Land) as a Result of All Processes [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. The "soil content" of a quantity refers to the vertical integral from the surface down to the bottom of the soil model. For the content between specified levels in the soil, standard names including content_of_soil_layer are used.
attributes.description: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. The "soil content" of a quantity refers to the vertical integral from the surface down to the bottom of the soil model. For the content between specified levels in the soil, standard names including content_of_soil_layer are used.
attributes.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)

attributes.longname: Gross Primary Production on Tree Tiles as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: defined as 1/(turnover time) for each soil pool. Use the same pools reported under cSoilPools

attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Turnover Rate of Each Model Soil Carbon Pool

attributes.comment: Dissolved inorganic carbon-14 (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration
attributes.description: Dissolved inorganic carbon-14 (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
attributes.longname: Dissolved Inorganic Carbon-14 Concentration

attributes.comment: Surface upward flux of nitrous oxide (N2O) from vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass), litter (dead plant material in or above the soil), soil.
attributes.description: Surface upward flux of nitrous oxide (N2O) from vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass), litter (dead plant material in or above the soil), soil.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Land N2O Flux

attributes.comment: The rate of synthesis of carbon-13 in biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ("producers") expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. For example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is referred to as the net primary production.
attributes.description: The rate of synthesis of carbon-13 in biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ("producers") expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. For example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is referred to as the net primary production.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Carbon-13 Mass Flux out of Atmosphere Due to Gross Primary Production on Land [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: In some models part of nitrogen (e.g., root exudate) can go directly into the soil pool without entering litter.
attributes.description: In some models part of nitrogen (e.g., root exudate) can go directly into the soil pool without entering litter.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Nitrogen Mass Flux from Vegetation Directly to Soil

attributes.comment: "Litter" is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between "fine" and "coarse" is model dependent. "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.
attributes.description: "Litter" is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between "fine" and "coarse" is model dependent. "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.
attributes.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
attributes.longname: Carbon Mass in Litter on Grass Tiles

attributes.comment: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.
attributes.description: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Deforested Biomass That Goes into Product Pool as a Result of Anthropogenic Land-Use Change

attributes.comment: Flux of Nitrogen from the land into the atmosphere due to all processes other than fire
attributes.description: Flux of Nitrogen from the land into the atmosphere due to all processes other than fire
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Nitrogen Lost to the Atmosphere (Including NHx, NOx, N2O, N2) from All Processes Except Fire

attributes.comment: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Vegetation" means any plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. Plants are autotrophs i.e. "producers" of biomass using carbon obtained from carbon dioxide.
attributes.description: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Vegetation" means any plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. Plants are autotrophs i.e. "producers" of biomass using carbon obtained from carbon dioxide.
attributes.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
attributes.longname: Carbon Mass in Vegetation on Grass Tiles

attributes.comment: Total Nitrogen added for cropland fertilisation (artificial and manure). Relative to total land area of a grid cell, not relative to agricultural area
attributes.description: Total Nitrogen added for cropland fertilisation (artificial and manure). Relative to total land area of a grid cell, not relative to agricultural area
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Nitrogen Added for Cropland Fertilisation (Artificial and Manure)

attributes.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics. The specification of a physical process by the phrase "due_to_" process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. "Leaching" means the loss of water soluble chemical species from soil. Runoff is the liquid water which drains from land. If not specified, "runoff" refers to the sum of surface runoff and subsurface drainage.
attributes.description: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics. The specification of a physical process by the phrase "due_to_" process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. "Leaching" means the loss of water soluble chemical species from soil. Runoff is the liquid water which drains from land. If not specified, "runoff" refers to the sum of surface runoff and subsurface drainage.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Nitrogen Loss to Leaching or Runoff (Sum of Ammonium, Nitrite and Nitrate)

attributes.longname: Heterotrophic Respiration on Grass Tiles as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: Total NPP of grass in the grid cell
attributes.description: Total NPP of grass in the grid cell
attributes.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
attributes.longname: Net Primary Production on Grass Tiles as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.
attributes.description: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Carbon Mass in Soil Pool Above 1m Depth

attributes.comment: Flux of carbon as carbon dioxide into the land. This flux should be reproducible by differencing the sum of all carbon pools (cVeg, cLitter, cSoil, and cProducts or equivalently cLand) from one time step to the next, except in the case of lateral transfer of carbon due to harvest, riverine transport of dissolved organic and/or inorganic carbon, or any other process (in which case the lateral_carbon_transfer_over_land term, see below, will be zero data).
attributes.description: Flux of carbon as carbon dioxide into the land. This flux should be reproducible by differencing the sum of all carbon pools (cVeg, cLitter, cSoil, and cProducts or equivalently cLand) from one time step to the next, except in the case of lateral transfer of carbon due to harvest, riverine transport of dissolved organic and/or inorganic carbon, or any other process (in which case the lateral_carbon_transfer_over_land term, see below, will be zero data).
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Net Flux of CO2 Between Atmosphere and Land (Positive into Land) as a Result of All Processes [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: Percentage of grid cell covered by wetland. Report only one year if  fixed percentage is used, or time series if values are determined dynamically.
attributes.description: Percentage of grid cell covered by wetland. Report only one year if  fixed percentage is used, or time series if values are determined dynamically.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
attributes.longname: Wetland Percentage Cover

attributes.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.
attributes.description: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
attributes.longname: Sinking Particulate Iron Flux

attributes.comment: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. The "soil content" of a quantity refers to the vertical integral from the surface down to the bottom of the soil model. For the content between specified levels in the soil, standard names including content_of_soil_layer are used.
attributes.description: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. The "soil content" of a quantity refers to the vertical integral from the surface down to the bottom of the soil model. For the content between specified levels in the soil, standard names including content_of_soil_layer are used.
attributes.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
attributes.longname: Carbon Mass in Soil on Grass Tiles

attributes.comment: Vegetation height averaged over the shrub fraction of a grid cell.
attributes.description: Vegetation height averaged over the shrub fraction of a grid cell.
attributes.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
attributes.longname: Height of Shrubs

attributes.comment: The surface called "surface" means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. "Upward" indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics. The phrase "expressed_as" is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. "Nox" means a combination of two radical species containing nitrogen and oxygen NO+NO2. "Vegetation" means any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. "Litter" is dead plant material in or above the soil.
attributes.description: The surface called "surface" means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. "Upward" indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics. The phrase "expressed_as" is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. "Nox" means a combination of two radical species containing nitrogen and oxygen NO+NO2. "Vegetation" means any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. "Litter" is dead plant material in or above the soil.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Land NOx Flux

attributes.comment: will require some careful definition to make sure we capture everything - any human activity that releases nitrogen from land  instead of into product pool goes here. E.g. Deforestation fire, harvest assumed to decompose straight away, grazing...
attributes.description: will require some careful definition to make sure we capture everything - any human activity that releases nitrogen from land  instead of into product pool goes here. E.g. Deforestation fire, harvest assumed to decompose straight away, grazing...
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Nitrogen Mass Flux out of Land Due to any Human Activity

attributes.comment: in each soil layer, the mass of water in all phases, including ice.  Reported as "missing" for grid cells occupied entirely by "sea"
attributes.description: in each soil layer, the mass of water in all phases, including ice.  Reported as "missing" for grid cells occupied entirely by "sea"
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Water Content of Soil Layer

attributes.comment: Flux of CO2 from product pools into the atmosphere. Examples of "forestry and agricultural products" are paper, cardboard, furniture, timber for construction, biofuels and food for both humans and livestock. Models that simulate land use changes have one or more pools of carbon that represent these products in order to conserve carbon and allow its eventual release into the atmosphere, for example, when the products decompose in landfill sites.
attributes.description: Flux of CO2 from product pools into the atmosphere. Examples of "forestry and agricultural products" are paper, cardboard, furniture, timber for construction, biofuels and food for both humans and livestock. Models that simulate land use changes have one or more pools of carbon that represent these products in order to conserve carbon and allow its eventual release into the atmosphere, for example, when the products decompose in landfill sites.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Decomposition out of Product Pools to CO2 in Atmosphere as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: needed to separate changing vegetation C turnover times resulting from changing allocation versus changing mortality
attributes.description: needed to separate changing vegetation C turnover times resulting from changing allocation versus changing mortality
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Carbon Mass Flux from Vegetation to Litter as a Result of Leaf, Branch, and Root Senescence

attributes.comment: SUM of nitrate over all soil layers
attributes.description: SUM of nitrate over all soil layers
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Mineral Nitrate in the Soil

attributes.comment: added for completeness with Ra_root
attributes.description: added for completeness with Ra_root
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Respiration from Stem as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass), litter (dead plant material in or above the soil), soil, and forestry and agricultural products (e.g. paper, cardboard, furniture, timber for construction, biofuels and food for both humans and livestock).
attributes.description: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass), litter (dead plant material in or above the soil), soil, and forestry and agricultural products (e.g. paper, cardboard, furniture, timber for construction, biofuels and food for both humans and livestock).
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Mass of 13C in All Terrestrial Carbon Pools

attributes.comment: Primary (organic carbon) production by other phytoplankton components alone
attributes.description: Primary (organic carbon) production by other phytoplankton components alone
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
attributes.longname: Net Primary Organic Carbon Production by Other Phytoplankton

attributes.comment: Heterotrophic respiration is respiration by heterotrophs ("consumers"), which are organisms (including animals and decomposers) that consume other organisms or dead organic material, rather than synthesising organic material from inorganic precursors using energy from the environment (especially sunlight) as autotrophs ("producers") do. Heterotrophic respiration goes on within both the soil and litter pools.
attributes.description: Heterotrophic respiration is respiration by heterotrophs ("consumers"), which are organisms (including animals and decomposers) that consume other organisms or dead organic material, rather than synthesising organic material from inorganic precursors using energy from the environment (especially sunlight) as autotrophs ("producers") do. Heterotrophic respiration goes on within both the soil and litter pools.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Carbon-14 Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to Heterotrophic Respiration on Land [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: The rate of synthesis of carbon-14 in biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ("producers") expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. For example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is referred to as the net primary production.
attributes.description: The rate of synthesis of carbon-14 in biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ("producers") expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. For example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is referred to as the net primary production.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Carbon-14 Mass Flux out of Atmosphere Due to Gross Primary Production on Land [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.
attributes.description: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Nitrogen in All Terrestrial Nitrogen Pools

attributes.comment: Primary (organic carbon) production by the calcite-producing phytoplankton component alone
attributes.description: Primary (organic carbon) production by the calcite-producing phytoplankton component alone
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
attributes.longname: Net Primary Mole Productivity of Carbon by Calcareous Phytoplankton

attributes.comment: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Vegetation" means any plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. Plants are autotrophs i.e. "producers" of biomass using carbon obtained from carbon dioxide.
attributes.description: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Vegetation" means any plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. Plants are autotrophs i.e. "producers" of biomass using carbon obtained from carbon dioxide.
attributes.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)

attributes.comment: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Vegetation" means any plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. Plants are autotrophs i.e. "producers" of biomass using carbon obtained from carbon dioxide.

attributes.longname: Heterotrophic Respiration on Shrub Tiles as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: Heterotrophic respiration is respiration by heterotrophs ("consumers"), which are organisms (including animals and decomposers) that consume other organisms or dead organic material, rather than synthesising organic material from inorganic precursors using energy from the environment (especially sunlight) as autotrophs ("producers") do. Heterotrophic respiration goes on within both the soil and litter pools.
attributes.description: Heterotrophic respiration is respiration by heterotrophs ("consumers"), which are organisms (including animals and decomposers) that consume other organisms or dead organic material, rather than synthesising organic material from inorganic precursors using energy from the environment (especially sunlight) as autotrophs ("producers") do. Heterotrophic respiration goes on within both the soil and litter pools.

attributes.longname: Dry and Wet Deposition of Reactive Nitrogen onto Land

attributes.comment: "Litter" is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between "fine" and "coarse" is model dependent. "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.
attributes.description: "Litter" is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between "fine" and "coarse" is model dependent. "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.
attributes.cell_methods: area: time: mean where trees (comment: mask=treeFrac)

attributes.comment: Total autotrophic respiration from all belowground plant parts.  This has benchmarking value because the sum of Rh and root respiration can be compared to observations of total soil respiration.

attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Total Respiration from Roots as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: The mass (summed over all all layers) of liquid water.
attributes.description: The mass (summed over all all layers) of liquid water.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Soil Liquid Water Content

attributes.comment: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.
attributes.description: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Deforested Biomass That Goes into Atmosphere as a Result of Anthropogenic Land-Use Change [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. The water table is the surface below which the soil is saturated with water such that all pore spaces are filled.

attributes.comment: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Litter" is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between "fine" and "coarse" is model dependent. "Surface litter" means the part of the litter resting above the soil surface. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.
attributes.description: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Litter" is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. attributes.comment: Loss of soil nitrogen through remineralization and immobilisation. Remineralization is the degradation of organic matter into inorganic forms of carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus and other micronutrients, which consumes oxygen and releases energy. Immobilisation of nitrogen refers to retention of nitrogen by micro-organisms under certain conditions, making it unavailable for plants.
attributes.description: Loss of soil nitrogen through remineralization and immobilisation. Remineralization is the degradation of organic matter into inorganic forms of carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus and other micronutrients, which consumes oxygen and releases energy. Immobilisation of nitrogen refers to retention of nitrogen by micro-organisms under certain conditions, making it unavailable for plants.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Net Nitrogen Release from Soil and Litter as the Outcome of Nitrogen Immobilisation and Gross Mineralisation

attributes.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
attributes.longname: Net Primary Production on Shrub Tiles as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

attributes.comment: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Litter" is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between "fine" and "coarse" is model dependent. "Subsurface litter" means the part of the litter mixed within the soil below the surface. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.
attributes.description: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Litter" is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between "fine" and "coarse" is model dependent. "Subsurface litter" means the part of the litter mixed within the soil below the surface. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Nitrogen Mass in Below-Ground Litter (non CWD)

attributes.comment: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area litter (dead plant material in or above the soil).

attributes.comment: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Wood debris" means dead organic matter composed of coarse wood. It is distinct from fine litter. The precise distinction between "fine" and "coarse" is model dependent. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.
attributes.description: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Wood debris" means dead organic matter composed of coarse wood. It is distinct from fine litter. The precise distinction between "fine" and "coarse" is model dependent. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.
attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Nitrogen Mass in Coarse Woody Debris

attributes.comment: in each soil layer, the mass of water in liquid phase.  Reported as "missing" for grid cells occupied entirely by "sea"

attributes.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
attributes.longname: Liquid Water Content of Soil Layer
